name: Bogner® Shiva® 20th Anniversary
description: The Bogner Shiva Guitar Amp Head 20th Anniversary comes with a pair of KT88's and the amp is rated at 90 watts. The clean channel has an entire new boost circuit. Unlike the tone stack bypass boost on the other Shiva model this boost has a separate gain stage which brings this channel into Plexi territory when boost is engaged. The tone controls stay in the circuit and affect the sound.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Bogner Amplification.

name: Marshall® JCM800®
description: The Marshall 2203 was created in 1975 and was one of the first Mrshall Master Volume amps. The "JCM" stands for Jim's full initials — James Charles Marshall. Played by iconic artists such as Dave Grohl, John Frusciante, Slash and Kirk Hammet, the JCM800 boasts an impressive array of artists who lean on its distinct aggression for their sound.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Marshall Amplification PLC.

name: Marshall® JCM900®
description: Released in January 1990, the JCM900 boasted higher gain and lower noise coupled with the classic Marshall tone. The series was originally comprised of the single channel Hi-Gain Master Volume MK III and the two channel Hi-Gain Dual Reverb. Both amps contained a series FX loop, two line outputs and a high/low switch that could be used to drop the power from 100w to 50w. This all-valve amp is famous for its tone and roadworthiness while maintaining the original high gain and dual reverb functions. Channel A starts out clean and builds to a crunch while channel B drives the higher gain tones from smooth distortion to a searing scream. The JCM900 4100 is equipped with a series FX loop with its own level control for use with FX or stomp boxes.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Marshall Amplification PLC.

name: Ampeg® Heritage® B15N®
description: The Heritage B-15N by Ampeg delivers the same B-15 performance that many bass players have fallen in love with, plus some modern features. With this all-tube design, you get the iconic thump of 1964 and 1965 B-15 amplifiers in two distinct channels. The Heritage B-15N also features Baxandall EQ and selectable bias modes for extended tone control, and you can transport this amazing tone machine with the classic Ampeg flip-top design.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Yamaha Guitar Group, Inc.

meta.label: Power Tubes
meta.value: 2 x 6L6GC power tubes, and 1 x 5AR4 rectifier tube

name: BOSS® DS-1 Distortion
description: The BOSS DS-1 Distortion is a classic distortion pedal that has been the top-selling BOSS compact pedal ever since its release in 1978. The DS-1 delivers a hard-edged attack and smooth sustain that's been responsible for the signature sounds of countless rock and metal guitarists for decades. This pedal has become a staple in pedalboards worldwide and offers a uniquely diverse range of distortion tones with its simple three-knob interface for Tone, Level, and Distortion control.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Roland Corporation.

name: Morley® Bad Horsie®
description: The Morley Bad Horsie is Steve Vai's legendary signature wah pedal with an added Contour mode. Morley spent years working with Steve Vai taming this Bad Horsie and in 1996 released what would become one of the first artist signature pedals, and their best-selling wah of all time. The Bad Horsie features switchless operation - simply step on the treadle to engage the wah and step off to bypass. The wah has two modes: Bad Horsie Wah mode set to Steve's preferred tone and sweep, and Contour Wah mode which allows you to alter the frequency and output of the wah using the Contour and Level knobs.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Morley Products Group.

meta.label: Features
meta.value: Switchless optical design, Two wah modes, LED indication

name: BOSS® BD-2 Blues Driver®
description: Sweet, nuanced, and ultra-expressive, the BD-2 Blues Driver stands as an enduring icon in the world of guitar overdrive since its release in 1995. Its innovative BOSS analog circuit design behaves like a tube amp, providing natural, touch-responsive gain that's not possible with standard overdrive pedals. The BD-2 is renowned for its sensitivity and expressive range, with a multi-stage clipping circuit inspired by actual tube amplifiers. This design delivers a very organic playing experience, with drive character and harmonic content that changes with your picking attack and cleans up beautifully as you roll back your guitar's volume. The versatile Blues Driver handles everything from transparent clean boost to rich, saturated drive tones that cut through any mix.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Roland Corporation.

name: BOSS® CE-2W Waza Craft Chorus
description: Released in 2016 to celebrate the 40th anniversary of BOSS effects, the CE-2W Waza Craft Chorus faithfully recreates the classic CE-2 chorus sound that defined countless hit tracks in the 1980s and beyond. This premium analog pedal features the bucket-brigade delay (BBD) circuit design of the original, providing that unmistakable warm, spacious modulation that guitarists have sought after for decades. The CE-2W offers three modes: Standard mode reproduces the legendary CE-2 chorus exactly, while CE-1 mode provides access to the stereo chorus and vibrato sounds of the world's first chorus pedal. The pedal also includes modern upgrades such as stereo outputs and variable depth control for the CE-1 chorus sounds that weren't available in the original pedals. Made in Japan with meticulous attention to detail, the CE-2W represents the pinnacle of BOSS design and craftsmanship.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Roland Corporation.

meta.label: Controls
meta.value: Rate, Depth, Mode Switch (Standard/CE-1 Chorus/CE-1 Vibrato)

meta.label: Connectors
meta.value: Input, Output A (Mono), Output B, DC In

name: Klon® Centaur®
description: The Klon Centaur is a legendary overdrive pedal designed by Bill Finnegan between 1994 and 2008. Finnegan, working with MIT graduate Fred Fenning, spent over four and a half years developing the circuit to create an overdrive that would emulate the distortion of a tube amplifier at high volume without altering the underlying tone. The Centaur is credited with popularizing 'transparent' overdrives and features a unique dual-ganged gain pot that blends clean and overdriven signals. At low gain it acts as a boost, while higher settings deliver pure distortion. Only around 8,000 units were produced, and the pedal has become highly sought after, with prices reaching $20,000 by 2024.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Klon.

meta.label: Circuit
meta.value: TL072 op amp with 1N34A germanium diodes, 18V internal

meta.label: Power Supply
meta.value: 9V Battery or AC Adapter (internal voltage doubler to 18V)

name: Ibanez® TS808 Tube Screamer®
description: The Ibanez TS808 Tube Screamer is one of the most iconic overdrive pedals in guitar history. First released in 1979, it was developed by Maxon's Susumu Tamura as a competitor to the Boss OD-1. The name 'Tube Screamer' came when Sammy Ash of Sam Ash Music remarked that the pedal sounded like a 'screaming tube amp.' The TS808 is renowned for its dynamic, touch-sensitive distortion and throaty midrange boost that helps guitars cut through a mix. Its legendary JRC4558D overdrive circuitry, with two diodes in the op-amp feedback loop, was groundbreaking at the time. Stevie Ray Vaughan famously used the TS808 to achieve his trademark juicy strat tone, and it remains one of the most copied and modified overdrive pedals ever made.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Hoshino Gakki Co., Ltd.

meta.label: Circuit
meta.value: JRC4558D op-amp with diode clipping in feedback loop

name: Fulltone® OCD®
description: The Fulltone OCD (Obsessive Compulsive Drive) is a versatile overdrive pedal first released in 2004. Its unique combination of MOSFET transistors and voltage-controlled clipping delivers remarkably tube-like tones with extraordinary touch sensitivity and dynamic response. The pedal features an HP/LP switch that toggles between British-style tones (High Peak) with an upper-midrange push, and more transparent American-flavored tones (Low Peak). The OCD can run at 18 volts for increased headroom, and includes an internal switch for true bypass or enhanced buffer modes. It has become known for its transparency, power, and versatility across a wide range of gain settings.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Fulltone Musical Products, Inc.

meta.label: Circuit
meta.value: Class A 2N5457 JFET input, MOSFET clipping

name: ProCo® RAT®
description: The ProCo RAT is a legendary distortion pedal designed by Scott Burnham and Steve Kiraly in Kalamazoo, Michigan in 1978. Named after the rat-infested basement where it was designed, only twelve 'Bud Box' prototypes were initially produced before mass production began in 1979. The RAT's distinctive sound comes from its LM308 op-amp gain stage with hard-clipping diodes. The unique Filter control is a low-pass filter that can sweep almost the entire audio spectrum from 475Hz to 32KHz. The RAT has spawned numerous variants including the RAT2, Turbo RAT (with LED clipping), and You Dirty RAT (with germanium diodes), and its simple yet effective circuit has made it one of the most enduring distortion pedals in rock history.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Pro Co Sound, Inc.

meta.label: Circuit
meta.value: LM308/OP07DP op-amp with 1N4148 silicon diode clipping

name: Electro-Harmonix® Big Muff Pi®
description: The Electro-Harmonix Big Muff Pi is one of the most iconic fuzz pedals ever made. First released in 1969 as a collaboration between Mike Matthews and Bob Myer, the original 'Triangle Big Muff' became the first overwhelming success for Electro-Harmonix. Unlike earlier fuzz pedals that used germanium transistors, the Big Muff employs silicon transistors in a four-stage circuit: a clean boost driving two clipping stages, followed by a tone recovery stage. This design delivers massive sustain with harmonic distortion and a distinctive thick, creamy fuzz tone. David Gilmour famously used it on Pink Floyd's Animals and The Wall, and it became integral to the sound of Smashing Pumpkins, Dinosaur Jr., and countless alternative rock bands through the 1980s and 1990s.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Electro-Harmonix.

meta.label: Circuit
meta.value: Four silicon transistor stages with passive tone stack

name: Marshall® Super Lead 100® 'Plexi'
description: The Marshall 1959 Super Lead 100, commonly known as the 'Plexi' due to its gold-colored Plexiglas control panels, is one of the most iconic guitar amplifiers ever made. Produced between 1966 and 1981, it was developed after Pete Townshend of The Who asked Jim Marshall to build him a more powerful amp. The result was a 100-watt beast that, paired with two 4x12 speaker cabinets, created the legendary 'Marshall stack'. The Super Lead features two channels with four inputs (often jumpered together for a thicker tone) and no master volume - it needed to be played loud to sound its best. The celebrated Plexi-era amps made between 1967 and 1969 are considered the most revered, and their aggressive, midrange-heavy sound helped establish Marshall's signature 'crunch' tone.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Marshall Amplification PLC.

name: Marshall® JTM 45®
description: The Marshall JTM45 is the first guitar amplifier produced by Marshall, initially released in 1963. Named for Jim and Terry Marshall (JTM) and rated at 45 watts (45), it was developed after London guitarists requested an alternative to imported American Fender amplifiers. While based on the Fender Bassman circuit, the JTM45 featured an all-aluminum chassis, Celestion speakers in a closed cabinet, and modified feedback circuitry that gave it a distinctive British snarl. Early versions used 5881 power tubes, later replaced by KT66s. The amp was first publicly tested at the Ealing Club in September 1963 and went on to be used by David Gilmour, The Rolling Stones, and Jimi Hendrix. The 2x12 combo version was famously used by Eric Clapton on the legendary 'Beano' album with John Mayall's Bluesbreakers.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Marshall Amplification PLC.

name: Marshall® Silver Jubilee®
description: The Marshall Silver Jubilee was introduced in 1987 to celebrate 25 years of Marshall amps and Jim Marshall's 50 years in rock 'n' roll, hence the model number 2555 (25/50). Produced for only a single year, these amps quickly became rare collector's pieces fetching premium prices. Based on the JCM800 2203 and 2204 models, the Silver Jubilee added more gain via diode clipping and a half-power mode to achieve great tones at lower volumes. The distinctive silver covering and chrome panel made it visually iconic, while its tone caught the attention of guitarists like Slash, who used it extensively. In 2015, Marshall reissued the amp as the 2555X with improvements including better speaker output options and fixed switching circuitry.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Marshall Amplification PLC.

name: Mesa/Boogie® Dual Rectifier®
description: The Mesa/Boogie Dual Rectifier made its debut in February 1992 and marked a new paradigm in high-gain heavy guitar. Originally developed for the hair metal bands of the 80s, it arrived just as the Seattle grunge movement was changing the musical landscape. The amp features selectable tube or silicon diode rectification - tube rectification provides a 'spongier' feel with more elastic string response, while silicon diodes offer tighter attack and more headroom. This dual rectification system gave the amp its name. The original two-channel design featured Orange (Clean/Vintage modes) and Red (Modern mode) channels, delivering a scooped midrange, ominous low end, and ripping harmonic-laden top end. In 2025, Mesa/Boogie released the 90s Dual Rectifier reissue based on the original specs.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Mesa/Boogie Ltd.

name: Mesa/Boogie® JP-2C®
description: The Mesa/Boogie JP-2C is John Petrucci's signature amplifier, a modern reissue of the legendary Mark II C+ that he has used throughout his career with Dream Theater. Mesa Boogie collaborated with Petrucci to bring back the beloved C+ circuitry with 21st-century updates geared towards the live performer. The amp features three independent channels with three voicing modes (Clean, Mark IIC+, or Shred), two assignable 5-band graphic equalizers, and 60/100W switchable power. Modern features include a built-in CabClone cabinet simulator, all-tube spring reverb, buffered tube FX loop, and full MIDI control. Made in Petaluma, California with high-quality materials.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Mesa/Boogie Ltd.

name: Mesa/Boogie® Lone Star®
description: The Mesa/Boogie Lone Star was designed to exceed players' expectations of both tone and versatility from a vintage and modern boutique amp without compromise. Inspired by the pivotal Mark I, the Lone Star features stunning performance with the interaction of three cascading gain controls unlocking historic lead sounds. The amp includes Tube Rectifier Tracking which auto-assigns the most stylistic rectifier circuit based on the 10/50/100-watt power settings - tube rectification at lower wattages for authentic vintage feel, and silicon diodes at 100 watts for more punch and headroom. The amp delivers huge warmth from 6L6 power tubes with two independent channels, each with fully-independent controls and all-tube long spring reverb.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Mesa/Boogie Ltd.

name: Fender® Twin Reverb®
description: The Fender Twin Reverb was introduced in 1963 as one of the first black-panel-era amps and remains one of the most iconic clean amplifiers ever made. Featuring dual 12" speakers, diode rectification, spring reverb, tremolo, and four 6L6GC tubes producing 85 watts, it was the most powerful amp Fender had ever made. The celebrated Blackface era (1963-1967) used the AB763 circuit, considered the pinnacle of Fender circuit design. The Twin has been used by countless legendary artists including Mark Knopfler, David Gilmour, Chuck Berry, The Beatles, Jimi Hendrix, Eric Clapton, Jerry Garcia, and Kurt Cobain. Its copious clean headroom has made it a studio and stage staple for over six decades.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Fender Musical Instruments Corporation.

name: Fender® Deluxe Reverb®
description: The Fender Deluxe Reverb was introduced in 1963 by incorporating an onboard spring reverb tank to the newly redesigned Fender Deluxe amplifier. The Blackface models (1963-1967) featuring the AB763 circuit are considered the pinnacle of Fender circuit design. This 22-watt tube amplifier is powered by a pair of 6V6GT power tubes with a GZ34 rectifier, delivering the typical blackface 60's sparkle with a scooped clean sound but with more smooth breakup, sag and compression than its bigger siblings. It has found its way into more recording studios, clubs and bars than any other Fender amp, making it one of the most popular amps among all Fender models for decades.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Fender Musical Instruments Corporation.

name: Fender® Princeton Reverb®
description: The Fender Princeton Reverb is a compact, tube-driven combo guitar amplifier introduced in 1964 as part of Fender's Blackface era lineup. Designed by Leo Fender during the company's pre-CBS ownership, it evolved from the original 1946 Princeton student model. The Princeton Reverb is the smallest blackface/silverface Fender amp with both tremolo and reverb. With a 10-inch speaker run by a 12-15W dual 6V6 amp, it delivers a true 'American' Fender tone with punchy, responsive lows together with chimey highs. The Black Panel Princeton Reverb is one of the crown jewels of mid-60s combo amps and has been among the most widely used recording amps since its introduction.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Fender Musical Instruments Corporation.

name: Diezel® VH4®
description: The Diezel VH4 is the iconic first Diezel amp, created by Peter Diezel in 1994 when he was dissatisfied with commonly available amps. It revolutionized the industry with its 4-channel design and individual inserts. The four channels - Clean, Crunch, Mega and Lead - each have dedicated gain, EQ and master volume controls. The Clean channel produces Diezel's signature sparkling chime, while the high-gain Mega and Lead channels deliver the tight precision distortion that made guitarists like Adam Jones (Tool), Neal Schon (Journey), and James Hetfield (Metallica) early adopters. Each power tube has a fault indicator and separate fuse for reliability.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Diezel Amplification.

name: EVH® 5150 III®
description: The EVH 5150 III was developed by Eddie Van Halen and Chip Ellis of Fender, modeled heavily on the original Marshall Superlead that Eddie himself had used for many years. The three channels (Clean, Crunch and Lead) deliver signature melodic overtones with increased saturation, gain and improved low-mid frequency definition. The 100W head features eight 12AX7 preamp tubes and four 6L6 matched power tubes that generate wide open, sparkling articulate highs with a controlled bass response heard in Eddie's unmistakable rhythm playing. The 5150III 100S Head is identical to the setup Eddie Van Halen most recently toured with, featuring his exact custom modifications including an adjustable bias port.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright EVH Gear / FMIC.

name: Peavey® 6505®
description: The Peavey 6505 Series burst onto the hard rock stage in the early 90s and went on to create the sound of modern heavy metal. It has been the undisputed go-to guitar amp for scores of rock, hardcore, and metal bands since 1992. The 6505 is essentially the renamed 5150 after the EVH trademark change. Known for its raw tone, relentless power, and road-proven reliability, the 6505 delivers 120 watts from five 12AX7 preamp tubes and four 6L6GC power tubes. Famed metal producers and engineers like Andy Sneap and Colin Richardson often discuss how the amp sits perfectly in a mix, with Guitar Player Magazine noting its use on Machine Head's Burn My Eyes 'defined a generation of guitar tone.'
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Peavey Electronics Corporation.

name: Soldano® SLO-100®
description: The Soldano SLO-100 (Super Lead Overdrive 100) was designed by Mike Soldano and released in 1987 as the first production model from Soldano Custom Amplification. Hand-built and pushing the boundaries of high-gain guitar tone, it was an immediate success at the 1987 NAMM Show. Its thick, high-gain tones attracted lead guitarists like Joe Satriani, Warren DeMartini, George Lynch, and Mick Mars. Eddie Van Halen used an SLO during the early 1990s and later based his own Peavey 5150 on it. The amp features a cascading-gain preamp structure with five 12AX7 tubes, while four 6L6GC power tubes provide 100 watts with tight low-end. A key part of its success is that overdriven tones are created entirely in the preamp section, so it doesn't require ear-splitting volume levels to sound its best.
copyright: All images and product descriptions are copyright Soldano Custom Amplification.
